full_text: Great to be out chatting with the lovely residents of Pendlebury and Clifton today for brilliant local Labour candidate Sophia Linden. Labour members, councillors and myself had some lovely chats today so thank you to all residents who stopped for a natter x https://t.co/6LF0PGFKbs

Lovely to see the community garden on the corner of Horsham st in Langworthy today with local councillors. It’s a lovely little green oasis created by residents for residents. Lots of planting going on from apple trees to sunflowers, a lovely place to sit in the nice weather.🪴 https://t.co/Kvft6PPLq0

Great to chat yesterday with residents for the brilliant @VoteWarmishamPC in Pendleton and Charlestown with Labour councillors and members. Was also lovely to see the amazing @albion_ccf who were doing a litter pick. An inspirational group of youngsters who do Salford proud. https://t.co/7qGrhHZR3N

Brilliant to see these great north west members standing for Labour’s National Policy forum elections. Labour needs a transformative policy platform to deliver for communities. https://t.co/0zUeNlm5Oa

Amazing work today by @albion_ccf cadets. Really transformed the local area and they were doing this on their school holidays too! Real Salford pride in action there, well done guys x https://t.co/nK4KYl5DBh

In one of the richest economies in the world foodbanks shouldn’t need to exist. @SalfordFoodbank are providing a lifeline to so many who are struggling. It was great to meet the brilliant staff and volunteers yesterday. For help or to donate visit https://t.co/Le6qiMirYv https://t.co/F9hcxZOgOW
Amazing news to hear that @SalfordCRadio’s future has been secured. Fantastic for the community and the people of Salford. https://t.co/qFv43zo1Gk

Wishing a peaceful Ramadan Mubarak to all observing in Salford and beyond x 
#RamadanMubarak https://t.co/m41UmtvBjZ

Solidarity with @ucu strikers in Manchester this morning. This battle is about securing a better quality of life for staff, a better education for students, and bolstering our economy because unis and higher education institutions are hotbeds of innovation and creativity ✊ https://t.co/Vqz8MYwHa5

Great to hear @salfordladsclub have been awarded extra funding from the National Lottery Heritage Fund & the government’s Culture Recovery Fund. After a battle to survive through the pandemic they can continue on with their amazing work in the community. https://t.co/vWuwnPlYps
The financial pressure on unpaid carers has become untenable. They support our loved ones, it’s time Govt gave them the financial support they deserve. https://t.co/n9MkLLGBLf
That Salford is the only Greater Manchester area not awarded levelling up category 1 priority is fundamentally wrong. Govt must reassess this decision urgently!!! https://t.co/TCDDprzCj0

The pension injustice faced by 1950s born women is a scandal. Many of the women affected are now struggling to make ends meet, with some even forced to use food banks. Today I met with @WASPIint Salford & Eccles chair Judith to continue to pledge my support to the campaign. https://t.co/XTNpvk0dOs

Great to support @ucusalford @ucu @nw_ucu 
workers yesterday at Media City as they were on strike for the #FourFights demanding fair pay, job security, manageable workloads and fair treatment across the Higher Education Sector. #OneOfUsAllOfUs https://t.co/ZoGhNkKyNP

Great to speak to striking @CHEP_UKI @unitetheunion @Unite_NorthWest workers on the picket line in Trafford Park yesterday with @salford_mayor 

All they ask is fair pay so I hope that with the skyrocketing cost of living crisis, talks with management are positive. https://t.co/xAZaz0KM31

PM promises summit with nuke test veterans:" Mirror's revelations were met with gasps today as Rebecca told the House of Commons that the number of men in UK nuclear weapons tests exposed to dangerous radiation was far higher than previously reported"
https://t.co/R9NDpy54Bz

Today I asked the PM to investigate @DailyMirror & @fleetstreetfox groundbreaking story bringing to light damning data hidden in a footnote of a 1988 Gov report for decades, showing over 2314 nuclear testing veterans were exposed to dangerous radiation not just 159 quoted in 2008 https://t.co/qOriGrB9oX

The sacking of 800 P & O workers so that they can be replaced by exploited cheaper labour is one of the most shameful episodes in our industrial history. The Govt legally can and must act now to demand these jobs are reinstated. https://t.co/U0e1T8VnMV

Today, 5 years since the Westminster Bridge attack we remember PC Keith Palmer, tragically killed on duty whilst protecting us, and all those who tragically lost their lives. Our thoughts are with their loved ones and we thank those to whom we owe our lives and continuing safety.

Great to join hospitality, transport workers and charities today in Parliament to launch @unitetheunion @FairHospitality  #GetMeHomeSafe campaign. 

Late night workers deserve free and safe transport home.

Check out the campaign here https://t.co/0FJJtQNpnr https://t.co/8Bb3m3caz6

The contribution of the Irish diaspora to all aspects of political, commercial, community & cultural life in the UK is incalculable, and the closeness & warmth between UK & Ireland goes from strength to strength. My speech today on the contribution of the Irish Diaspora in the UK https://t.co/DSRpcwIWYT
This is absolutely abhorrent! Full solidarity with @RMTunion staff.  Govt must urgently take action https://t.co/cawZHd8mdx

In-work poverty is a national scandal which will be exacerbated further by the Govt’s inaction on the cost of living crisis. 75% of children already grow up in poverty living in a household where at least one person works. The Govt must take urgent action 👇 https://t.co/zmhWnExn0w

Fantastic to see Nazanin and Annoosheh finally reunited with their families after too many years away. Well done to all involved in finally bringing their horrific detention to an end. https://t.co/aNao1rrAtJ

Radio by the community, for the community. @SalfordCRadio is a little gem and is presented by volunteers from across Salford. They have brought Salford together and supported so many community organisations over the years. Now they need our support 👇 https://t.co/WyYapg9g1r
A short update on my position on Ukraine. https://t.co/glSTuB1fji

Great @labourirish event at the Irish World Heritage Centre tonight. Fantastic speakers incl Salford’s own @MikeMcCusker15 and the band was great too. Also moving to hear Bob Sopel, Chair of the Ukrainian Centre in Manchester and to express our solidarity at this horrific time. https://t.co/DTd5PpLsb1

This is the time for Government to wrap their arms around households, not hit them with an illogical tax hike & more cuts.

Join me, fellow MPs, a range of unions & movements online on March 16 to demand urgent action to tackle the cost-of-living crisis.
https://t.co/nf4tfUtQqc

Today I stopped by the almost complete Swinton Greenway with local @LabourEccles and @SwintonLabour Councillors, to help plant a few trees along this amazing route from Monton to Swinton. Opening fully in June for anyone fancying a wander, dog walkers, cyclists and runners!🚶‍♂️🚴‍♀️🌲 https://t.co/XWUnaDMxbH

The Gov must scrap its illogical and unfair national insurance contribution increase. It will be disproportionately loaded onto younger and lower paid workers. Gov should be shielding households from the cost of living crisis, not pushing them over the edge. https://t.co/ShXBwVeOMR
With a cost of living crisis and rising energy bills, it’s more important than ever to invest in the future of Green energy, Green buildings and retrofitting homes to bring down energy costs.

Great to welcome @Ed_Miliband and @AndyBurnhamGM to Salford today with @salford_mayor to see the work of @SalfordUni and @energy_house2. A unique global building that replicates conditions in climates across the globe to see how homes of the future can be energy efficient. https://t.co/CUq00i0uxB

I have heard from Salford constituents this morning who have met their Ukrainian family members at the Polish border only to struggle to progress visas and secure biometric interviews. Govt must progress swift emergency visas to reunite families urgently at this horrific time. https://t.co/j18nmcTmqf

The Renters Reform Bill was announced in the 2019 and 2021 Queen's Speeches, but in 2022 it is still no further along. The Govt need to get moving and finally introduce this Bill, to ensure minimum decent home standards for renters and protection from no fault evictions. https://t.co/2CeyPG999v

Happy International Women's Day to all the amazing and inspiring women of Salford and beyond xxx https://t.co/kYDv0m7TYI
We need to see urgent and significant reforms to legal aid before the system collapses completely. Here are just a few key actions the Govt must take. https://t.co/XzkXRYa8mq

Legal aid is in crisis after 10 years of brutal cuts. Access to justice is the cornerstone of democracy but the fact is it is being rationed - my speech on the causes of this crisis and what action the Govt must urgently take to solve it. https://t.co/1aQx9uqMrj

It was so humbling to speak to so many people from the Greater Manchester Ukrainian community, and also to speak to Tanya and share solidarity with her family who were video calling from Ukraine during the ceremony 🇺🇦 https://t.co/aVOw4O0tUA

Today a joint British & Ukrainian flag was raised at Salford Town Hall to show solidarity with Ukrainian people during this horrific time. Great to see so many people from across Salford expressing solidarity. Our brilliant Ukrainian Cllr Tanya Burch helped to raise the flag 🇺🇦 https://t.co/FBkrmdzJNW
The test of progress however, is not adding more to the abundance of those who have much, it’s whether we provide enough for those who have too little.

4.3 million children in UK live in poverty and Govt are set to make this worse with a real terms benefits cut just as a cost of living crisis approaches and energy bills soar. In one of the richest economies in the world this is not inevitable, it is a political choice. https://t.co/WEnil5SQDl
Happy St David’s day to everyone celebrating in Salford and beyond today x https://t.co/9hnJ3mmnAz

Russia's invasion of Ukraine is utterly horrific.

Great result for First Manchester workers #JobsPayConditions ✊ https://t.co/QGqrzMrDrM

This is brilliant news 👏👏👏 https://t.co/lIeOPNzArK

Food insecurity is not some abstract horror created by an unknown force beyond our control that can only be addressed by benevolence. Hunger is a political choice. Access to food must be a legal right. https://t.co/R6W236O7qW

Babies in Gove’s constituency are likely to be healthier, wealthier & better qualified than those in North. Levelling up is meaningless if it can’t address these stark inequalities & I see little in the white paper that will reverse decades of brutal austerity #dontleaveusbehind https://t.co/BERNt6Svor

Tonight I voted against a real terms cut to social security benefits. Over 30 charities and organisations warned the Government that 6% (not the Gov's proposed 3.1%) was the basic increase needed to meet inflation. They were ignored, it was voted through & now people will suffer. https://t.co/ZaIXeSrXqp
Without serious and significant funding from government, their “levelling-up” agenda will be “consigned to the scrapheap of rhetorical epithets” https://t.co/cZ9lHDYxV8

2/ On the 20th January over 415,000 pupils were off school and 15% of teachers were absent too, and this could have been avoided. The Minister talks about testing ventilation levels first with CO2 monitors but many schools haven’t even got them yet, never mind air purifiers.

1/ Last year Germany promised all schools an 80% subsidy for air purifiers to ensure education wasn’t disrupted. Our Govt has ‘only just’ agreed to 9000 (we have over 300,000 classrooms!), and SAGE told Govt how important this was in May last year! https://t.co/3nfUZytZOp

Yesterday I spoke in support of a parliamentary petition calling on the Govt to renationalise the NHS, scrap Integrated Care Systems, end PFI and scrap the Health and Care Bill, which will reduce our rights to access healthcare and allow privatisation of our NHS. #ScrapNHSBill https://t.co/FvHI9cMK2g
2/ I would like everyone to get vaccinated so that they are protected, but through encouragement, and informing of the benefits not coercion.

1/ I voted against plans for mandatory vaccination of NHS staff as it would not have effectively stopped transmission in health settings without regular testing and would have caused a staffing crisis. Now Gov has finally listened to health unions and professional bodies. https://t.co/3F5f3pUBIa

2/2 Staff at the office have been working so hard and it looks like they have turned a corner but let me know if you’re still not getting your letters.

Yesterday I spoke in the debate on #BuildingSafetyBill. Residents and leaseholders must have statutory protection from ALL fire safety defect costs and a national Gov led mission to carry out the required works at pace. Last night I voted against #ElectionsBill, that requires voters to present ID before they can vote. With election turnout already low, this Bill will make it harder for communities already disengaged in politics to vote, in a blatant attempt from the Tories to rig elections.

Every day brings another party, another scandal.
 
This shows further contempt for the British people, many who couldn’t be with loved ones as they lay ill or dying as these parties took place. The PM’s authority to govern is gone and he has got to go. https://t.co/BiO29RhbrH

Businesses want to address the climate crisis & improve our air quality, but Gov must assist GMCA by allowing a delay to the scheme, and deliver a financial package that supports businesses and protects the residents of GM from bearing the crippling costs of this Gov scheme.

We are in the midst of a cost of living crisis, with real wages set to fall and annual energy bills expected to rise by 50%. But today the Gov voted against cutting VAT on household energy bills. 

Gov must get a grip on this crisis, and now seriously examine public ownership. https://t.co/ly6KMbQwC8

Millions of people are living in fuel poverty, struggling to cope with rising energy prices, and being forced to decide whether to heat their home or feed their family. Change is needed. Starting with a VAT cut on energy bills, and then public ownership of our energy system. https://t.co/tLhDSNAyd9

The next generation will be the ones who bear the brutal costs of inaction on climate change. As #COP26 host the Govt has a moral duty to secure their future, starting with a review of the national curriculum, to ensure climate change and sustainability is embedded in it. https://t.co/g68gPSvoPF

13/13 Nothing on climate change!!!! the week before COP26!! Current NetZeroStrategy needed bulking up today. Its already reported that it will not get the UK close to its net zero goal by 2050, and that without the funds might fail to meet even its current limited ambition.

12/13 Fuel duty freeze and reforms to alcohol duty to help local pubs and producers will be welcome but the cut in the Bank Surcharge, a huge tax cut for banks at a time when so many people are struggling is crass, and cutting air passenger duty the week before COP26 just bonkers

11/13 Biz rates - Retail, hospitality and leisure businesses to get business rate relief of 50% over the next 12 months which is welcome but where is the money coming from to plug the gap? could significantly hit local government revenue without rebalancing.

10/13 Scraps for Local Gov: grant funding 4.8bn over three years. Councils needed at least 1.5bn per year for social care….as well as billions to rebuild already hollowed out services – Salford has already been forced to cut £222m from its budgets since 2010/11. Not sustainable.

9/13 Family Hubs - Pledge of £500m to support young families but it is important to note that between 2011 and 2017, the government cut the funding of Sure Start centres by two thirds. The budget represents a loss of £700 million against what they have cut.
8/13 National living wage was increased to £9.50 but in detail it seems real wages are set to fall by 0.1% in 2022 as living costs increase.

7/13 Cost of living - OBR expects inflation to average 4% over the next year, means cost of living will be more expensive in addition to energy bills already going up –  Nothing at all set out to help people who will struggle with skyrocketing energy bills.

6/13  Universal Credit - taper rate will be cut by 8% but according to budget documents, less than a third of families losing £20 a week from their Universal Credit will benefit from the changes to the taper – also only helps half the people claiming UC  so many still struggle.

5/13 As @NP_Partnership have said today “the scale of the levelling up fund means it’ll have a limited productivity impact, as each bid is only large enough in scale to address specific local challenges – and will not go far enough in tackling the north-south divide."

4/13  Also important to note that as far as I can tell the amounts announced today were the existing £1.7bn "levelling up fund", not new money, but to level up capital spending across the country to London levels fund would need at least £30bn extra per year

3/13  If levelling up means anything we need to see multiple bids permitted and granted for large scale town centre regenerations in Eccles, Swinton, Pendleton/Langworthy as well as investment in local facilities in Ordsall, Pendlebury, Clifton and Irlams O'th' Heights and more.

2/13 Levelling up – I wish….but good news our constituency bid – the Salford rise project on the Crescent has been granted and the Chancellor responded postively to @salfordcouncil and my letters of support. Problem - allowing one application bid per constituency is not enough

1/13 How will the Budget affect Salford? Some initial thoughts: Building safety - Virtually zero on the #claddingscandal leaving thousands in continued anguish. Recycled announcements - the developer levy tax, the £11.5bn affordable homes funding and the £5bn for cladding removal

Some observations on chancellors statement to protect workers and businesses so far:

1. Job retention scheme moving in right direction but no specific obligation to keep staff on, just a hope that businesses will do the right thing.

There’s no excuse: any landlord who, as a result of suspended rent obligations, can‘t afford to pay mortgages on a property or indeed their own, should in turn be covered by the govt’s promise to pause mortgages or its wider business support package if they operate as a business.

A 3-month eviction delay is not good enough for those falling ill, self-isolating, having hours cut, caring for children or who lose their job. The government must instead temporarily suspend rent obligations for everyone affected by coronavirus and unable to pay the rent.

It’s clear that now is not the time for half-measures. But that's exactly what we‘re seeing for renters - the govt’s proposal risks loading debt onto those who can least afford it, storing up problems for just a few months' time. The poorest must not pay the price of the crisis.

Here are 12 points the Government must implement urgently:

11. Pushing for international co-operation on all elements of the response, including the development of a free global vaccine, at the G7 tomorrow.

12. Using every lever of government to direct the production of ventilators by UK manufacturers.

8. Requisitioning premises for additional medical facilities necessary to deal with the outbreak.

9. Matching the commitment to "whatever extra resources our NHS needs" to social care.

10. Commitment from government to daily broadcast media briefings to keep everyone informed.

6. An increase in the rate of Universal Credit credit and an end to the 5 week wait - people who find themselves losing work will not get sick pay.

7. A right to work from home for those with underlying health conditions.

5. Emergency measures on debt and essential payments. Those sick and self-isolating stand to lose hundreds of pounds in pay and run the risk of not being able to meet the cost of essential payments for mortgages, rent, increased utility bills and other debts.

3. Boost resources to HMRC and JobCentre Plus to deal with immediate claims.

4. Support for Local Authorities & funding for food banks. Many low paid workers rely on food banks, which are experiencing a drop in donations & will see a decline in volunteers due to self-isolation.

Further we need this comprehensive 12-point financial care package for the public and support for businesses:

1. An immediate increase in statutory sick pay, which lags behind European countries.

2. Extending statutory sick pay to all workers including those in self-employment.

We will bring power, wealth and pride back to communities everywhere, bringing people together, reviving our towns & cities, building our shared future. That is our path to power. Change does not come easily. But together we can – and will - change our country forever.

We must take on our broken political system. People and working class communities who voted Leave and Remain, from South London to South Yorkshire, have all been neglected and by distant, undemocratic political institutions and elites.

We will expose and fight Johnson's narrow agenda. Because the challenges we face - from a volatile & wildly unequal world economy to the existential threat of climate change – are ones we solve together, including with our European neighbours. We cannot shut out the world.

Johnson will use Brexit to hand more to the powerful. Expect trade deals that sell out our assets, reduce people’s control over their lives & lower our rights & standards. Expect divisive immigration rules that force low-paid domestic & migrant workers into a race to the bottom.

Johnson can no longer just talk about "taking back control". He can no longer blame Brussels. When he doesn’t deliver for the people he will face the question of: in whose interests are those powers now being wielded.

Those of us who wanted to remain and reform raised the economic dangers of leaving but failed to understand that in communities like mine, people often couldn’t see how things could get worse. The call to “take back control” resonated where trust had eroded.

Britain’s departure from the EU comes after what have been difficult years for us all. Many of us are rightly worried about the future. It breaks my heart that despite our bold manifesto & their record, the Tories used Brexit to convince people they were change candidates.
The mark of a civilised society is how it treats its most vulnerable https://t.co/d7mnSACFdD

A Labour government will make publicly owned energy networks responsible for rolling out electric vehicle charging points across the country, to help the U.K. rapidly transition to low carbon, clean forms of transport ⚡️#GreenIndustrialRevolution 

https://t.co/BEMlK69KFb

Ultimately, we need infrastructure that is sustainable, affordable and answerable to you - not the investment banks on Wall Street, multinational conglomerates from Hong Kong to the United States, and sovereign wealth funds from China to Qatar that own our energy networks.

Publicly owned networks will invest in skills and protect workers rights, terms and conditions, working with energy unions to co-ordinate just transition pathways for workers affected by decarbonisation

Labour will establish national and regional energy agencies and support the creation of new bodies at the municipal and community level, transforming our energy system into one that is modern and democratic - accountable to you, not shareholders.

Remember the stories about private grid companies paying out £13 billion in dividends over just 5 years -  https://t.co/fxQHWIeBB6 and overcharging customers by £7.5 billion - https://t.co/yZdY6js3cY? 

That will end under a Labour government.

Public energy agencies will have the power and direct responsibility to deliver Labour’s ambitious climate change targets. Instead of pocketing excess profits, they will build out connections to parts of the country with high solar, wind and tidal potential.

Public energy agencies will be tasked with tackling fuel poverty and protecting energy as a human right – making good on Labour’s promise that the energy transition must go hand-in-hand with social justice

Private energy networks have ripped off customers and failed to invest enough to tackle climate change.

We'll need publicly owned networks to bring vast amounts of renewable energy online and to make energy affordable for households. This is our plan.

Essentially, this deal relies almost entirely on (welcome) investment by the private sector which is already happening. It leaves you wondering – what is the point of this government?

There will be a massive global market for offshore wind in the future, but all we are told is that the government will “continue it’s export support programmes”. So move along, nothing to see, leave it to Liam Fox.

The UK is the world’s largest market for offshore wind. Offshore wind should be to the UK what tech is to California and cars are to Germany. But the UK has a trade deficit in the technology – a tragedy - and the government are not taking the action needed to reverse that.

What about skills development, the training, retraining and investment needed to ensure a smooth transition for workers into these new jobs? That will also be left almost entirely to the private sector.

Rather than taking measures to ensure that new jobs are unionised, well paying, with good terms and conditions, the government will “participate” in an “Investment in Talent” group. This is a feeble commitment.

As @RMTunion note, there are real concerns in the industry about sub-contracting and deregulation. But the deal does nothing to ensure high employment and safety standards across the offshore energy sector. It does not mention trade unions – not once.
As @GMB_union and @unitetheunion note, the empty yards in Fife are a “sobering reminder of long-term political failure at both Holyrood and Westminster.”

Otherwise, the government will leave everything to the private sector’s Offshore Wind Growth Partnership. It will establish a non-binding “target” for UK content, and promises a road map for how this “could” be achieved. Pathetic.

UK-based manufacturers like BiFab have struggled to compete with state-backed competitors across Europe and the Middle-East. Does this sector deal ‘level the playing field’? No. It re-announces an existing programme (the Strength in Places Fund). Disappointing.

The government’s ambition is to deliver “up to” 30GW by 2030. This is nothing like enough to meet our climate targets, and following the collapse of the government’s nuclear plans, and hostility towards other forms of renewable energy, raises questions for our energy security.

Some thoughts on today’s offshore wind sector deal.
Summary: The ‘deal’ is basically a description of what the private sector is already doing. It is NOT a plan by government to go further than business-as-usual to create good jobs and protect the climate.

I’m so glad that people are finally talking about our high streets. But it’s enormously disappointing to see the Tories tinker around the edges because of their obsessive free market ideas. There’s a crisis in our high streets. Labour has a plan to end it.

And we’d work with councils to deliver free public Wi-Fi in town centres. This has worked so well in Newcastle, Sheffield and several London boroughs. It’s a great way to make our high streets more usable and flexible. It’s a win-win situation: why wouldn’t a government do this?
We would introduce annual revaluations of business rates, ensure a fair appeals system and review the business rates system to bring it into the 21st century. It’s common sense.

We’d ban ATM charges and stop bank branch and Post Office closures. Sixty bank branches are closing every month. If a town’s bank closes, it can be a catastrophe for anyone in the area who’s got mobility issues, and it makes life harder for everyone.
We would provide free bus travel for under 25s and improve local bus services by encouraging franchising or public ownership. Because strong high streets need the best transport links.

We’d establish an empty shop register – a list of landlords of empty shops in each local authority. There are 25,000 empty retail and leisure premises in GB, and it should be as easy as possible to get them back into use.
So here’s what that decent policy platform looks like. It’s called Labour’s five point plan. It’s the bold, radical vision for our town centres – and a serious plan for how we’d deliver it.

The Tories say they'd like to bring empty spaces into use. It’s an empty, hypocritical gesture. Saying you’d like something doesn’t help our high streets. You need a decent policy platform – otherwise you’re just pretending to care.

They all mentioned digital services tax too. But they know Hammond's designed that so it *won't* stop tech giants underselling high streets. Will raise a pittance and is scheduled to kick in only when the tech giants start to enjoy the Tories’ cut in their corp tax. It’s a sham.

@RidgeOnSunday @MarrShow Hammond, Brokenshire and Andy Street all propose turning shops into flats. It’s like a bad joke. That’s not rejuvenating high streets. It’s destroying them by turning them into residential properties. If you want housing, build council homes, like Labour will!

Disappointed that both @RidgeOnSunday and @MarrShow chose to highlight the Tories’ lazy and vapid high streets policy – and said nothing about Labour’s bold and concrete five point plan for high streets.
